questions.text: A patient is admitted with H. influenza meningitis. Cefotaxime is preferred over ampicillin in this patient because:

options.label: A
options.text: Cefotaxime is effective orally whereas ampicillin is not

options.label: B
options.text: Cefotaxime is more effective against H. influenza having altered penicillin binding proteins.

options.label: C
options.text: Cefotaxime is cidal drug whereas ampicillin is static

options.label: D
options.text: Cefotaxime is more active against beta lactamase producing strains of H. influenza.

questions.correct_answer: D. Cefotaxime is more active against beta lactamase producing strains of H. influenza.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Cefotaxime is more active against beta-lactamase producing strains of H. influenzae.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • One of the main reasons cefotaxime is preferred over ampicillin in the treatment of H. influenzae meningitis is due to its activity against beta-lactamase producing strains. Many strains of H. influenzae produce beta-lactamase, an enzyme that hydrolyzes the beta-lactam ring of ampicillin, rendering it ineffective. Cefotaxime, being a third-generation cephalosporin, is resistant to this enzyme and can effectively treat beta-lactamase producing strains of H. influenzae. Cefotaxime is primarily given intravenously or intramuscularly, not orally. Ampicillin can be given both orally and parenterally. Both cefotaxime and ampicillin target penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs). However, the resistance of H. influenzae to ampicillin is primarily due to the production of beta-lactamase, not the alteration of PBPs. Both cefotaxime and ampicillin are bactericidal agents. They kill bacteria by inhibiting the synthesis of the bacterial cell wall.

questions.text: Regarding the antibacterial action of tobramycin, which of the following statements is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Antibacterial activity is often reduced by the presence of an inhibitor of cell wall synthesis

options.label: B
options.text: It continues to exert antibacterial effects even after plasma levels decrease below detectable range

options.label: C
options.text: Efficacy is directly proportionate to the time that the plasma level of the drug is greater than the minimal inhibitory concentration

options.label: D
options.text: It has strong antibacterial activity against Salmonella

questions.correct_answer: B. It continues to exert antibacterial effects even after plasma levels decrease below detectable range
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. It continues to exert antibacterial effects even after plasma levels decrease below detectable range

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Aminoglycosides like tobramycin can actually act synergistically with cell wall synthesis inhibitors like beta-lactams in certain gram-positive infections. This is because the destruction of the cell wall can facilitate the uptake of the aminoglycoside into the bacterial cell. This phenomenon is known as the "post-antibiotic effect" (PAE). It refers to the continued suppression of bacterial growth after brief exposure of organisms to antibiotics and even after levels of the antibiotic are below the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC). Aminoglycosides, like tobramycin, exhibit this effect against many bacteria. The efficacy of aminoglycosides is more closely related to their peak plasma concentrations (peak/MIC ratio) rather than the time their plasma concentration remains above the MIC. This is referred to as concentration-dependent killing. While aminoglycosides have activity against many gram-negative bacteria, Salmonella strains are often resistant to aminoglycosides, so they are not the first choice for treating Salmonella infections.

Ans. C. Clostridium difficile is the common organism implicated in the causation of Pseudomembranous colitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Intravenous vancomycin is not typically used for pseudomembranous colitis. Instead, oral vancomycin is used because it achieves high concentrations in the colon, where the infection is located. Bezlotoxumab is a monoclonal antibody against toxin B of Clostridium difficile. While it can reduce the recurrence of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) in patients who are at high risk for CDI recurrence, it does not "kill" the bacteria. Instead, it neutralizes one of the toxins produced by the bacteria. Clostridium difficile is indeed the common organism implicated in the causation of Pseudomembranous colitis. The disease arises from the toxin production of this bacterium, typically after antibiotic therapy has disrupted the normal gut flora.

questions.text: A 36 years old woman recently treated for leukemia is admitted to the hospital with malaise, chills and high fever. Gram stain of blood reveals the presence of gram negative bacilli. The initial diagnosis is bacteremia and parenteral antibiotics are indicated. The record of the patient reveals that she had severe urticarial rash, hypotension and respiratory difficulty after oral pencillin V about 6 months ago. The most appropriate drug should be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Aztreonam

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A severe urticarial rash, hypotension, and respiratory difficulty after penicillin V intake are indicative of a severe penicillin allergy, possibly anaphylaxis. In patients with a history of severe penicillin allergy, cross-reactivity with other beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g., cephalosporins, carbapenems) is a concern.
  • • Breaking down the options:
  • • Ampicillin plus sulbactam: This combination is a beta-lactam/beta-lactamase inhibitor. Given her history of severe reaction to penicillin, it would not be an appropriate choice due to the risk of cross-reactivity. Cefazolin: A first-generation cephalosporin, which is also a beta-lactam antibiotic. While the risk of cross-reactivity between penicillins and first-generation cephalosporins is lower than with other cephalosporins, it's still present. Thus, it may not be the safest choice. Aztreonam: This is a monobactam antibiotic that is specifically formulated to treat gram-negative bacterial infections. Importantly, it does not have cross-reactivity with other beta-lactam antibiotics, making it safe for those with penicillin allergies. Imipenem plus cilastatin: Imipenem is a carbapenem, another class of beta-lactam antibiotics. There's a potential (though small) risk of cross-reactivity with penicillins.

questions.text: A post operative patient developed septicemia and was empirically started on combination chemotherapy by a new resident doctor. However, when the patient did not respond even after 10 days of antibiotics treatment, the review of the charts was done. It was found that that the resident doctor had started the combination of antibiotics which was mutually antagonistic in action. Which of the following is the most likely combination that was given?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Ampicillin and Chloramphenicol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Mostly two bactericidal or two bacteriostatic drugs can be combined together to produce synergistic or additive effect. However, in most cases, a bactericidal and a bacteriostatic drug combination is antagonistic.
  • • Ampicillin and Chloramphenicol: These two antibiotics can be antagonistic when used together. Ampicillin is a bactericidal agent that inhibits cell wall synthesis, while chloramphenicol is bacteriostatic and inhibits protein synthesis. When a bacteriostatic antibiotic (like chloramphenicol) is used in combination with a bactericidal antibiotic (like ampicillin), it can inhibit the action of the bactericidal drug, as bactericidal agents generally require actively dividing bacteria to be effective. Vancomycin and Amikacin: Both are bactericidal, and they act on different targets. Vancomycin acts on the bacterial cell wall, while amikacin acts on the 30S ribosomal subunit. They are not known to be antagonistic. Cephalexin and Gentamicin: Cephalexin acts on the bacterial cell wall, while gentamicin targets the 30S ribosomal subunit. They are both bactericidal and are not known to have an antagonistic relationship. Ciprofloxacin and Piperacillin: Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone that inhibits DNA gyrase, while piperacillin is a penicillin derivative that disrupts cell wall synthesis. They are not known to be antagonistic and can be used in combination.

Ampicillin is a bactericidal agent that inhibits cell wall synthesis, while chloramphenicol is bacteriostatic and inhibits protein synthesis. When a bacteriostatic antibiotic (like chloramphenicol) is used in combination with a bactericidal antibiotic (like ampicillin), it can inhibit the action of the bactericidal drug, as bactericidal agents generally require actively dividing bacteria to be effective.
  • • Vancomycin and Amikacin: Both are bactericidal, and they act on different targets. Vancomycin acts on the bacterial cell wall, while amikacin acts on the 30S ribosomal subunit. They are not known to be antagonistic.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the pediatric clinic with a 2-week history of an evolving cough. The mother reports that the child initially had a mild cough with cold-like symptoms that has progressed to episodes of severe coughing followed by a high-pitched "whoop" sound during inhalation. The episodes are often followed by vomiting. The child is afebrile and has not received all of his scheduled immunizations. Based on the clinical presentation, which is the preferred antibiotic for treatment?
questions.explanation:

The preferred treatment for children and adults with pertussis is azithromycin. Azithromycin is often preferred because of its shorter treatment course and better side-effect profile.
